articles.headline: To Ease Pain of Trump’s Trade War: $12 Billion in Aid for Farmers
articles.snippet: The move drew swift condemnation from many farm groups and lawmakers, including several Republicans, and signaled that the president is digging in on his tariffs.
articles.abstract: The move drew swift condemnation from many farm groups and lawmakers, including several Republicans, and signaled that the president is digging in on his tariffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration announced on Tuesday that it would provide up to $12 billion in emergency relief for farmers hurt by the president’s trade war, moving to blunt the financial damage to American agriculture and the political fallout for Republicans as the consequences of President Trump’s protectionist policies roll through the economy.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: Ivanka Trump Is Shutting Down Her Fashion Brand
articles.snippet: President Trump’s elder daughter, a top White House adviser, is shutting down the company more than a year after stepping away from the company.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s elder daughter, a top White House adviser, is shutting down the company more than a year after stepping away from the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ivanka Trump, President Trump’s elder daughter and a top White House adviser, said on Tuesday that she was shutting down her namesake fashion brand more than a year after stepping away from the company amid concerns over how Mr. Trump’s family might profit from his presidency.

articles.headline: E.U. to Offer Trade Proposals in Bid to Ease Tensions
articles.snippet: But the plans may fall short of appeasing President Trump, who has expressed skepticism at past trade pacts and branded the European Union as a “foe.”
articles.abstract: But the plans may fall short of appeasing President Trump, who has expressed skepticism at past trade pacts and branded the European Union as a “foe.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — European negotiators on Wednesday will present several ideas to the Trump administration for easing a trade clash with the United States, including forging a new deal among the world’s biggest automobile exporters.

articles.headline: Where Guns Go to Be Reincarnated
articles.snippet: Steel from firearms melted down at mills around the country is used for construction, mining and more.
articles.abstract: Steel from firearms melted down at mills around the country is used for construction, mining and more.
articles.lead_paragraph: What should America do with its unwanted guns?
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Jenn Ackerman

articles.headline: U.S. Businesses Are Bullish Amid Worldwide Instability
articles.snippet: Private-sector optimism is widespread, with risks from tariffs, deficits and global tensions outweighed by profit-plumping tax cuts and deregulation.
articles.abstract: Private-sector optimism is widespread, with risks from tariffs, deficits and global tensions outweighed by profit-plumping tax cuts and deregulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Potential perils are in plain sight: An intense and unpredictable tariff battle is alarming businesses across the country. The annual federal deficit is heading toward $1 trillion. Credit card debt is soaring. And the synchronous wave that lifted every world economy at the year’s start has dissipated.

articles.headline: What’s Behind a Pitch for the Little-Guy Investor? Big Money Interests
articles.snippet: The newly formed Main Street Investors Coalition says it wants to protect the rights of mom-and-pop investors. But its main complaint seems to be financial firms’ social consciousness.
articles.abstract: The newly formed Main Street Investors Coalition says it wants to protect the rights of mom-and-pop investors. But its main complaint seems to be financial firms’ social consciousness.
articles.lead_paragraph: The group calls itself the Main Street Investors Coalition.

articles.headline: As Greek Wildfire Closed In, a Desperate Dash Ended in Death
articles.snippet: A New York Times correspondent reports from the ashes of a seaside resort town devastated by fire and death.
articles.abstract: A New York Times correspondent reports from the ashes of a seaside resort town devastated by fire and death.
articles.lead_paragraph: MATI, Greece — They nearly reached the water.

articles.headline: Michael Cohen Releases Tape of Trump Discussing Hush Money for Playboy Model
articles.snippet: Michael D. Cohen, President Trump’s former personal lawyer, escalated their dispute by releasing a secret recording of a conversation they had about payments to a former Playboy model.
articles.abstract: Michael D. Cohen, President Trump’s former personal lawyer, escalated their dispute by releasing a secret recording of a conversation they had about payments to a former Playboy model.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s former personal lawyer, Michael D. Cohen, escalated his dispute with the president on Tuesday by releasing a secret recording of a conversation in which Mr. Trump appears to have knowledge about hush money payments to a former Playboy model who said she had an affair with Mr. Trump.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt, Maggie Haberman and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Tech Companies Like Facebook and Twitter Are Drawing Lines. It’ll Be Messy.
articles.snippet: Big tech companies are asking themselves where their responsibilities start and stop. Sorting that out will be complicated and may end up increasing their power.
articles.abstract: Big tech companies are asking themselves where their responsibilities start and stop. Sorting that out will be complicated and may end up increasing their power.
articles.lead_paragraph: From its earliest days, Silicon Valley has been animated by near-absolutist understanding of free speech. Other than exceptions for fraud, pornography or specific threats, the prevailing view among many tech platforms has been to allow pretty much anyone to post pretty much anything. These sensibilities are even enshrined in American law, which gives companies broad immunity from prosecution for what their users post.

articles.headline: How the Trump Tax Cut Is Helping to Push the Federal Deficit to $1 Trillion
articles.snippet: Corporate income tax collections are near a 75-year low, as a share of the economy, after a new law reduced rates and allowed companies to deduct investments immediately.
articles.abstract: Corporate income tax collections are near a 75-year low, as a share of the economy, after a new law reduced rates and allowed companies to deduct investments immediately.
articles.lead_paragraph: The amount of corporate taxes collected by the federal government has plunged to historically low levels in the first six months of the year, pushing up the federal budget deficit much faster than economists had predicted.

articles.headline: Yosemite National Park Evacuated Amid Threat From Fire
articles.snippet: A nearby 38,000-acre wildfire turned one of the country’s most popular national parks into a virtual ghost town on Wednesday.
articles.abstract: A nearby 38,000-acre wildfire turned one of the country’s most popular national parks into a virtual ghost town on Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOSEMITE VALLEY, Calif. — Gone were the massive granite monoliths of Half Dome and El Capitan, lost in the shroud of a ghostly and acrid layer of smoke. Gone, too, were the cascading waterfalls that plunge to the floor of Yosemite Valley, their famed beauty uselessly out of sight.
articles.byline: By John Branch, Jennifer Medina and Henry Fountain
